newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ bond yields end higher, investors sidelined.
newsitem.headline: NZ bond yields end higher, investors sidelined.

text.p: New Zealand government bond yields ended higher on Wednesday after a light session as investors took to the sidelines following a second missile attack by the United States on Iraq.
The upcoming October 12 election was another reason to do nothing.
Some stock returned to the market on Tuesday night and there was one seller in the long end this afternoon, according to one Wellington bond dealer.
"I don't think people are convinced yet that we are at the top of the market (in yield) given the Iraqi situation and with the election cmoing up," he said.
"Which means the institutional end holders are probably sitting in the wings to a certain extent, just waiting to see where things will pan out," he said.
He said the short end of the curve was not so badly off, supported in part by the steady stream of swap, Euro and Samurai activity.
A close watching brief was being kept on U.S. markets.
Further out, the market turning was turning its attention to next week's fiscal update and the Reserve Bank's economic projections.
Economists expect the Reserve Bank to re-assert its view that conditions need to remain firm to contain inflation.
